body:
Just a shot in the dark but I don't think MLflow does (or can) support a local directory as artifact storage while using a remote backend store (e.g. an SQL-like database). Even if no errors are displayed on the CLI during launch, most probably the tracking server cannot find the artifact giving the local path, hence the unexpected behavior (you could verify this looking at the browser console logs while on the tracking server UI). 
Maybe using `file:/opt/mlflow/mlruns` instead of just `/opt/mlflow/mlruns` could tweak this but I doubt it will work anyway.

Maybe someone with more expertise can confirm this or give you some insight on your use case scenario nonetheless.

@ntakouris The following code saves artifacts in the `foo` directory. Am I missing something?

```
mlflow server --backend-store-uri sqlite:///mlflow.db --default-artifact-root foo -h 0.0.0.0 -p 5000
```

```python
import mlflow
import uuid

client = mlflow.tracking.MlflowClient(
    tracking_uri="http://localhost:5000",
)
name = uuid.uuid4().hex
eid = client.create_experiment(name)
print(client.get_experiment(eid))

run = client.create_run(eid)
run_id = run.info.run_id
client.log_artifact(run_id, local_path=__file__)
```

Output:

```
<Experiment: artifact_location='foo/9', experiment_id='9', lifecycle_stage='active', name='cd17250444dc4ac48667def6574409c7', tags={}>
```

@browser-bug So, if I set sftp to localhost it's going to work? That's a weird workaround.

@harupy I was using the sqlite variant before, and it did create a `mlruns.sqlite` and an `mlruns/` directory at the same directory when I did run the python (training) script command. But it was using that without the mlflow server.

Let's say I do `cd ~/testing && mlflow server --backend-store-uri sqlite:///mlflow.db --default-artifact-root foo -h 0.0.0.0 -p 5000`

I then save some artifact: the `~/testing/foo` directory is created, but nothing is inside:
```
ntak@sys76-ntakouris:~/testing$ ls foo/
ntak@sys76-ntakouris:~/testing$ ls
foo  mlflow.db
```

I also tried `file:///foo` and it works as expected: it tells me that I don't have permission. However, if I create the directory as I stated above: `/opt/mlflow/mlruns` and chmod 777 it (so there's no ownership problem), the same thing happens (no artifacts)!

@ntakouris Are you creating a new experiment? Can you insert the following code in your script and check what it prints out?

```python
with mlflow.start_run():
    print(mlflow.get_artifact_uri())
```
@harupy The `mlflow.tracking.MlflowClient` class does not contain a method `get_artifact_uri()`. I am passing in `tracking_uri="http://localhost:5000"` as expected, though.

@ntakouris

If so, please run `print(run)`. The output should contain `artifact_uri`:

```
<Run: data=<RunData: metrics={}, params={}, tags={}>, info=<RunInfo: artifact_uri='foo/9/bf13e18440aa46eeac3120684c65d137/artifacts', end_time=None, experiment_id='9', lifecycle_stage='active', run_id='bf13e18440aa46eeac3120684c65d137', run_uuid='bf13e18440aa46eeac3120684c65d137', start_time=1652169699156, status='RUNNING', user_id='unknown'>>
```

@harupy 

```
info=<RunInfo: artifact_uri='/opt/mlflow/mlruns/1/211770d1922f4d77934ddde7bac1126a/artifacts', end_time=None, experiment_id='1', lifecycle_stage='active', run_id='211770d1922f4d77934ddde7bac1126a', run_uuid='211770d1922f4d77934ddde7bac1126a', start_time=1652172411458, status='RUNNING', user_id='unknown'>>
```

... but the directory `/opt/mlflow/mlruns` is empty. 

I figured out the problem right now: it does not communicate with the server and instead tries to save this locally. 

So, instead of saving to the os `/opt/mlflow/mlruns`, it saves it inside the docker container where the training script is running. (So, the tracking server is not used to save the artifacts).

Imagine that the tracking server is running on machine A, and the training script on machine B. Artifacts will end up getting stored in machine B instead of machine A.

@ntakouris Got it, can you try running this command and check where artifacts are stored?

```
mlflow server --backend-store-uri sqlite:///mlflow.db --default-artifact-root mlflow-artifacts:/mlartifacts -h 0.0.0.0 -p 5000
```

doc: https://www.mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#artifact-stores

@harupy they are still being saved inside the container (wrong machine).

From the docs you linked: `mlflow-artifacts:/` is supposed to link to whatever existing artifact storage there is (ex. s3). I've not configured s3. I just want the artifacts to be stored on the local directory, of the machine/container that the tracking server runs.
